Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Campus Design: Western New Mexico University's Small Campus Cyberinfrastructure Grant

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Western New Mexico University (WNMU) is constructing a robust, faster and more contemporary fiber network that supports research and educational initiatives. The enhanced network allows for 10Gbps speeds between research-intensive network segments for internal transfers, and provides critical redundant fiber paths for the WNMU network. The network enhances the regional research capacity and contributes to improving data sharing capabilities needed by emerging research initiatives at WNMU. These projects include examining variables that affect retention of at risk STEM students and helping STEM students participate in biology and chemistry research projects that require technologically modern online tools. The network improvements also increase capacity and enable the network to scale up to meet WNMU's evolving bandwidth needs. By removing old multimode fiber, WNMU is taking the foundational steps of establishing the essential infrastructure to competitively contribute to more complex and scalable projects, such as the Science DMZ.

WNMU has long-standing collaborations with other educational institutions and these collaborations are leveraged fully in this project; WNMU's partner, CHECS-Net (New Mexico's multi-institutional collaboration for sharing technology, expertise, and pricing information), provides guidance and experience. Moreover, as a rural, open-enrollment, Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) with a mission to serve students who are considered "at risk," the network is providing these students access and practice with contemporary science skills enhanced by practicing with modern cybertools and cyberinfrastructure. The changes are providing these students the opportunity for them to effectively contribute to the scientific capital and workforce needs of the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Laying the Groundwork for a Research Network and Science DMZ

The primary goal of this proposal was to bring the Cyberinfrastructure at Western New Mexico University (WNMU) to a level that could support a dedicated research network and Science DMZ.  Western’s new cyberinfrastructure connects research-intensive buildings with its Information Technology (IT) datacenter via 10Gbps single-mode fiber.  These connections bypass firewall and all traffic shaping measures.  The newly established core and edge routing are capable of moving large data sets, and are amenable for large flows by performance monitoring (Scrutinizer).  The replaced single mode fiber removes complications and errors the previous faulty and failing fiber were introducing in large flows.  Though the Science DMZ is not yet fully implemented, the proposal has greatly enhanced the capacity and efficiency of moving large data sets, which will drive the expansion of data intensive research at WNMU.  Full implementation is expected to be completed by 2019, with the introduction of a perfSONAR host and a high performance Data Transfer Node (DTN).

 

Fostering Distance Education in STEM fields

Over the last five years, the percentage of students attending online or via video conferencing has risen to over 50% of Western’s total enrollment.  The previous Cyberinfrastructure made teaching these classes difficult, particularly the more data/network demanding Science, Math and Network Technology courses.  WNMU fulfills a dual mission of community college and four-year institution, and this improved Cyberinfrastructure will enable more STEM courses for both.  By Fall of 2018, WNMU is scheduled to introduce additional programs online—including Calculus, Physics and ArcGIS—thanks to the upgraded network.  The enhanced network will serve as a keystone for further courses, as specialty software normally reserved for computer lab use may be served virtually.  Western is implementing a Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) project in Fall 2018 that will provide opportunity for increased STEM applications, research and education for our students.

 

Improving WAN Connectivity

Western’s proposal provided the necessary foundation pieces to improve its Wide Area Network (WAN) connectivity from 200 Mbps to 1Gbps.  The enhanced network is now also capable of receiving bandwidth from multiple sources, allowing for WNMU to take the next step of procuring redundant access to the internet.  This is just one step of the upgrade, as WNMU is collaborating with local Telecommunication companies to procure a second, redundant source of bandwidth for the campus, and is expecting to have this in place by 2019.

 

Enhancing Faculty and Student Research Outcomes

This improved Cyberinfrastructure resulted in improvements in research outcomes at WNMU.  In the previous five years, Western’s Natural Science faculty averaged 0.7 research articles published per year/faculty member.  Subsequent to the grant, this showed an increase, going from 0.7 to 1.3 such articles per year.  It also had a substantial effect on student research as well, increasing the number of research presentations at WNMU’s Annual Research Symposium from 10 to 17.  Western’s enhanced Cyberinfrastructure is improving opportunities for faculty and students to collaborate with researchers outside of WNMU.

Enabling Community Opportunities

Being a small school in a rural community, WNMU serves as the vanguard for technology, science and telecommunications for southwest New Mexico.  This proposal has provided the early steps for Western to become an IP Head for Grant County, allowing for other federal, state and city government institutions to combine bandwidth needs, and procure them at an affordable cost.  This broadening of campus network will also be paramount in promoting community events, broadcasts, and economic growth for the region.  Projects that will provide pathing to the city’s local library and consolidated school system are already underway, and should be completed by Fall of 2018.  Goals for this first segment include increase Dual Enrollment STEM offerings to local K-12 by 50%.
